text: And they blessed Rebekah, and said unto her, Thou art our sister, be thou the mother of thousands of millions, and let thy seed possess the gate of those which hate them.
text_kjv: And they blessed Rebekah, and said unto her, Thou art our sister, be thou the mother of thousands of millions, and let thy seed possess the gate of those which hate them.
text_niv: And they blessed Rebekah and said to her,“Our sister, may you increaseto thousands upon thousands;may your offspring possessthe gates of their enemies.”
text_esv: And they blessed Rebekah and said to her, “Our sister, may you become thousands of ten thousands, and may your offspring possess the gate of those who hate him!”
text_nlt: They gave her this blessing as she parted: “Our sister, may you becomethe mother of many millions!May your descendants be strongand conquer the cities of their enemies.”
text_msg: And they blessed Rebekah saying,You're our sister—live bountifully!And your children, triumphantly!
text_nasb: They blessed Rebekah and said to her, 'May you, our sister, Become thousands of ten thousands, And may your descendants possess The gate of those who hate them.'
context: Genesis 24 unfolds within a patriarchal society where family lineage and the continuation of the covenant were paramount. Rebekah's family, residing in Mesopotamia (specifically Haran), held a distinct cultural position as descendants of Nahor, Abraham's brother. Their customs and beliefs, while sharing common ancestry with Abraham, were likely influenced by Mesopotamian polytheistic practices, although the narrative suggests they retained some awareness of the God of Abraham. Marriage arrangements were typically strategic alliances orchestrated by families to secure prosperity, land, and offspring. A woman's primary value lay in her ability to bear children, especially sons, ensuring the family's survival and inheritance. The 'gate' mentioned was not merely a physical structure, but the center of civic and economic life, the place where decisions were made and authority resided. 'Possessing the gate' implied dominance and control over a city or region, signifying not just territorial ownership but also political and social influence. Blessings pronounced upon Rebekah carried significant weight, reflecting a belief in their power to shape future events. The blessing invoked upon Rebekah wasn't just a polite wish, but a potent declaration intended to impact her destiny. The concept of 'thousands of millions' (or myriad myriads) was a common hyperbolic expression indicating a vast, uncountable number, emphasizing the desire for her descendants to be incredibly numerous.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 24:60 is profound. It connects Rebekah's personal destiny to the overarching narrative of God's covenant with Abraham. The blessing pronounced upon her echoes God's promises to Abraham in Genesis 12, 15, and 17 regarding numerous descendants who would inherit the land. This highlights God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises through chosen individuals. The phrase 'mother of thousands of millions' isn't just a numerical aspiration; it signifies spiritual multiplication and the propagation of faith. It implies a lineage that extends beyond physical descendants to include those who embrace the faith of Abraham, becoming spiritual heirs to the covenant. The 'gate of those which hate them' symbolizes overcoming opposition and achieving victory in the face of adversity. This speaks to the enduring struggle between good and evil, and the ultimate triumph of God's people. It suggests that Rebekah's descendants, empowered by God, would not only survive but thrive, even amidst enemies. The blessing also underscores the importance of female figures in God's redemptive plan. Rebekah's willingness to leave her home and family to marry Isaac demonstrates faith and obedience, qualities that position her as a pivotal figure in the lineage of Christ. It's a prophetic affirmation of God's sovereign control over history and His ability to use ordinary people to accomplish extraordinary purposes. This verse is a testament to the power of blessing and its role in shaping destiny according to God's will.
application: In modern life, Genesis 24:60 offers several practical applications. Firstly, it reminds us of the power of spoken blessings. We should intentionally speak words of affirmation and encouragement over our families, friends, and communities, believing in their ability to shape lives positively. These blessings should be rooted in faith and aligned with God's Word. Secondly, the verse highlights the importance of embracing our roles in God's grand narrative. Like Rebekah, we are called to respond to God's call with faith and obedience, even when it requires leaving our comfort zones. This might mean stepping out in faith to pursue a new career, serve in ministry, or relocate to a different place. Thirdly, the blessing on Rebekah challenges us to consider our legacy. What impact will our lives have on future generations? We should strive to live in such a way that our descendants will inherit not only material possessions but also a strong faith and a commitment to God's purposes. Fourthly, the phrase 'possess the gate' encourages us to seek influence in our spheres of influence. This doesn't necessarily mean political dominance, but rather using our talents and resources to advance justice, compassion, and truth in our communities. Whether we work in education, business, or the arts, we can strive to be agents of positive change. Finally, this verse is a reminder of God's faithfulness. Even when we face opposition and adversity, we can trust that God will fulfill His promises in our lives and in the lives of our descendants. We should persevere in faith, knowing that God is working all things together for good.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for the example of Rebekah and the powerful blessing bestowed upon her. Help us to recognize the significance of the words we speak and to use them to bless and encourage others. Grant us the faith to embrace your calling in our lives, even when it requires sacrifice and uncertainty. May our lives be a testament to your faithfulness and a source of blessing for future generations. Empower us to influence our communities for good, to be agents of justice and compassion, and to stand firm against opposition. We pray that you would multiply our impact and use us to advance your kingdom. Help us to trust in your promises and to persevere in faith, knowing that you are working all things together for our good. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.
